variant.note: Highlights in Linguistics from Cambridge and CSLI Lectures on Deixis Charles Fillmore
variant.bodyText: The author studies the range of infor- mation that the speakers of a language possess about the sentences in their language by thoroughly examining one simple English sentence. Distributed for CSLI Publications
variant.subsectionHeader: Second Position Clitic and Related Phenomena
variant.subsubsectionHeader: Aaron L. Halpern and Arnold M. Zwicky, Editors
variant.bodyText: This collection of essays focuses on a special type of pronouns and auxiliary verbs, known as clitics. The book is unique in its depth and breadth of data, comparing several different languages to determine their similarities and differences.
variant.note: Contributors: Pilar Barbosa, Joseph M Fontana, Andrew Garrett, Liliane Haegeman, Mark Hale, Hans Hock, Eloise Jelinek, Patrick McConvell, Chiyo Nishida, Susan Pintzuk, Liljiana Progovac, Vesna Radanovic-Kocic, Steven Schaufele, Ann Taylor, Jindrich Toman, Olga Miveska Tomic, Dieter Wanner, C. Jan-Wouter Zwart
variant.construct: Makoto Kanazawa, Christopher Pition, and Henriette de Swart, Editors
variant.bodyText: The essays in this collection are based on the second Workshop on Logic, Language and Computation at Stanford, in 1993. It brought together researchers interested in natural language to discuss the current state of the art at the border- line of logic, linguistics and computer science.
variant.affiliation: Contributors: Mary Dalrymple, John Lamping, Fernando Pereira, Vijay Saraswat, Jan van Eijck, Kees van Deemter, Megumi Kameyama, Cleo Condoravdi, Mark Gawron, Friederike Moltmann, Henriette de Swart
variant.sectionHeader: CSLI Lecture Notes 1-57586-005-8 Hardback about $49.95 1-57586-004-X Paperback $22.95
variant.bodyText: This book develops a theory of meaning in ordinary language. The theory is strictly formalized on the basis of formal logic and the book contributes to the general discipline of Formal Semantics. Within this field it offers a synthesis between two leading paradigms. Studies in Logic, Language and Information 2
variant.figure: 1-881526-80-1 Hardback $64.95 1-881526-79-8 Paperback $22.95 A Theory of Aspectuality The Interaction Between Temporal and Atemporal Structure Henk J. Verkuyl
variant.figureCaption: Sentences may pertain to states or processes or events. They may express boundedness, duration, repetition, frequency, and many other forms of temporality. This text presents a theory about aspectual properties of sentences in natural languages.
variant.subsectionHeader: Restrictiveness in Case Theory Henry Smith
variant.bodyText: Within a unification-based framework, the author draws out pervasive patterns in the relationship between morpho- syntax "linking" and grammatical func- tion. Beginning with a detailed study of dative substitution in Icelandic, the author moves on to examine a wide array of synchronic and diachronic data.
46287-8 Hardback $59.95 Available in bookstores or from

variant.sectionHeader: l996 MEMBERSHIP. CHANGE OF ADDRESS AND EMAIL AND ORDER FORM MEMBERSHIP
variant.bodyText: Membership in the Association for Computational Linguistics is for the calendar year, regardless of when dues are paid. Membership includes a full year of the ACL journal, Computational Linguistics, reduced registration at most ACL-sponsored conferences, and discounts on ACL-sponsored publications. Payments for membership dues, fund donations, back issues, and proceedings may be made in Europe, Japan or the USA. Follow the instructions under the PAYMENT heading carefully. Provide all personal information, even if you have previously done so, lobe sure the ACL membership database is up-to-date Write leeibly, please!

Please IMMEDIATELY notify the ACL Office of address and email changes. Journal copies returned due to bad addresses will not be remailed until a $5.00 postage/handling fee is remitted. Email (if available) is used to distribute meeting, membership, and other announcements.
variant.listItem: IMPORTANT NOTE: Renewals must be received no later than 1 April 1996 to avoid late payment fee assessment. Membership categories include Regular Members and the following: Couples with the same mailing address may be Joint Members; they will receive only one set of publications, but each will be eligible for all other member benefits. Students taking a full-time program of courses and not earning a regular income may become Student Members WITH COPY OF CURRENT STUDENT ID. Students who are not Student Members because of their income can still participate in student activites as Student- Employed. Also available are Retired and Unemployed memberships. Late payment fees do not apply to new memberships.

Contributions may betas deductible, and companies may provide matching funds; check local regulations. Receipts are available upon request. Make checks payable to "THE WALKER FUND". Visa and Mastercard payments are also accepted.

variant.bodyText: Manuscripts for Computational Linguistics should be submitted on letter-size paper (8.5 by 11 inches, or A4), double-spaced throughout, including footnotes and references. The paper should begin with an informative abstract of approximately 150-250 words. Manuscripts must be written in English. Contact the editor regarding the possibility of electronic submission.
variant.subsectionHeader: Submissions may be made in any of the following categories:
variant.bodyText: Papers: This category includes contributions that report significant new research results in com- putational linguistics or that provide critical reviews of the literature on a particular topic. The length of a paper depends on its content, but it is suggested that manuscripts be limited to forty double-spaced pages. That is the equivalent of thirty journal pages. Each paper is fully refereed, being read by at least two members of the editorial board and usually by an additional expert in the particular subject area. The submission of an article to CL for refereeing means that the author certifies the manuscript is not copyrighted; nor has it been published or submitted for publication to another refereed journal. If any version of the paper has appeared, or will appear, in a non-refereed publication, the details of such publication must be made known to the Edi- tor at the time of submission. The final version of a paper tentatively accepted for publication must be accompanied by a Copyright Transfer Agreement signed by all of the authors or, in the case of a "work for hire," by the employer. This written transfer is necessary under the 1978 U.S. Copyright law. Letters to the Editor: This category includes statements of opinion on issues relevant to the readership. The Editor and the editorial board will evaluate the appropriateness of these con- tributions for inclusion.
variant.figure: Five copies of papers or three copies of letters should be sent to: Julia Hirschberg, CL Editor AT&T Research 600 Mountain Avenue, 2C-409 Murray Hill, NJ 07974, USA (+1 908) 582-7496; acl@research.att.com
variant.figureCaption: Squibs and Discussions: This category includes short articles reporting technical results, dis- cussions of results, algorithms, or new computational linguistic data or tools of interest to the journal readership. Submissions should generally not exceed eight double-spaced pages and should be submitted to:
variant.table: Pierre Isabelle, CL Squibs and Discussions Editor CWARC Communications Canada 1575 Chomedey Boulevard Laval, Quebec, CANADA H7V 2X2 (+1 514) 973-5801; isabelle@citi.doc.ca Book Section: Anyone interested in reviewing a book, or in suggesting a book for review, should contact the Book Review Editor; publishers may also submit copies of books for review directly to: Graeme Hirst, CL Book Review Editor University of Toronto Department of Computer Science Toronto, CANADA M5S 1A4 (+1 416) 978-8747; gh@cs.toronto.edu
variant.bodyText: The FINITE STRING: Send (a) summaries of research in progress — of particular interest would be perspectives on the activities at a particular institution; (b) announcements of meetings of potential interest to the membership; and (c) personal notes (e.g., honors, moving, changes in status) to The FINITE STRING Editor. Time-sensitive material should be received by the first day of the second month of each quarter to appear in the next issue. Submissions (where possible in electronic form) should be sent to:
variant.footnote: Richard Sproat, FINITE STRING Editor Bell Laboratories 600 Mountain Avenue, 2D-451 Murray Hill, NJ 07974, USA (+1 908) 582-5296; rws@research.att.com
variant.bodyText: Founded in 1962, the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) is the primary scientific and professional society for natural language processing research and applications. A European chapter was established in 1982. Besides publishing Computational Linguistics, the ACL holds international meetings (annually in North America, biennially in Europe) where the state-of-the-art in natural language processing research and development is presented. Recently, special interest groups on the Mathematics of Language, the Lexicon, Parsing, Generation, Computational Phonology, and Multimedia Language Processing have been formed; others are likely to be added.

Kathleen McKeown. ACL Secretaryaremurerj Guidelines for Submissions for Linguistics be submitted on letter-size paper (8.5 by 11 inches, or A4), double-spaced throughout, including footnotes and references. The paper
variant.abstract: should begin with an informative abstract of approximately 150-250 words. Manuscripts must be written in English. Contact the editor regarding the possibility of electronic submission. Submissions may be made in any of the following categories: category includes contributions that report significant new research results in computational linguistics or that provide critical reviews of the literature on a particular topic. The length of a paper depends on its content, but it is suggested that manuscripts be limited to forty double-spaced pages. That is the equivalent of thirty journal pages. Each paper is fully refereed, being read by at least two members of the editorial board and usually by an additional expert in the particular subject area. The submission of an article to CL for refereeing means that the author certifies the manuscript is not copyrighted; nor has it been published or submitted for publication to another refereed journal. If any version of the paper has appeared, or will appear, in a non-refereed publication, the details of such publication must be made known to the Editor at the time of submission. The final version of a paper tentatively accepted for publication must be accompanied by a Copyright Transfer Agreement signed by all of the authors or, in the case of a "work for hire," by the employer. This written transfer is necessary under the 1978 U.S. Copyright law. to the Editor: category includes statements of opinion on issues relevant to the readership. The Editor and the editorial board will evaluate the appropriateness of these contributions for inclusion.
variant.title: Five copies of papers or three copies of letters should be sent to:
variant.author: Julia Hirschberg
CL Editor
variant.affiliation: AT&T Research
variant.address: 600 Mountain Avenue, 2C-409 Murray Hill, NJ 07974, USA
variant.abstract: and Discussions: category includes short articles reporting technical results, discussions of results, algorithms, or new computational linguistic data or tools of interest to the journal readership. Submissions should generally not exceed eight double-spaced pages and should be submitted to:
variant.author: Pierre Isabelle
CL Squibs
Discussions Editor
variant.affiliation: CWARC Communications Canada

variant.degree: Section: interested in reviewing a book, or in suggesting a book for review, should contact the Book Review Editor; publishers may also submit copies of books for review directly to:
variant.author: Graeme Hirst
CL Book Review Editor
variant.affiliation: University of Toronto Department of Computer Science
variant.abstract: FINITE STRING: (a) summaries of research in progress — of particular interest would be perspectives on the activities at a particular institution; (b) announcements of meetings of potential interest to the membership; and (c) personal notes (e.g., honors, moving, changes in status) to The FINITE STRING Editor. Time-sensitive material should be received by the first day of the second month of each quarter to appear in the next issue. Submissions (where possible in electronic form) should be sent to:
variant.author: Richard Sproat
FINITE STRING Editor
variant.affiliation: Bell Laboratories
variant.address: 600 Mountain Avenue, 2D-451 Murray Hill, NJ 07974, USA
variant.abstract: Founded in 1962, the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) is the primary scientific and professional society for natural language processing research and applications. A European chapter was in 1982. Besides publishing Linguistics, ACL holds international meetings (annually in North America, biennially in Europe) where the state-of-the-art in natural language processing research and development is presented. Recently, special interest groups on the Mathematics of Language, the Lexicon, Parsing, Generation, Computational Phonology, and Multimedia Language Processing have been formed; others are likely to be added.
